newsitem.title: UK: Britain acts after Sea Empress oil spillage.
newsitem.headline: Britain acts after Sea Empress oil spillage.

text.p: Britain's Environment Agency said on Wednesday it had begun criminal prosecutions following last year's grounding of the Sea Empress oil tanker off South Wales.
The agency, a non-departmental government body, said summonses had been served on Milford Haven Port Authority and Mark Andrews, harbour master of Milford Haven Port.

"The Environment Agency is committed to taking a tough stance to protect the environment. Today's action shows that we are ready to use all the powers that are available to us in appropriate cases," Ed Gallagher, chief executive of the agency, said in a statement.

The tanker spilt 70,000 tonnes of oil in February 1996 in one of Britain's worst oil disasters. The spillage off Milford Haven was in an environmentally sensitive area and provoked a storm of criticism.

The charges are that each party caused a nuisance to the public with the discharge of crude and bunker oil, endangering the marine and coastal environment and posing a danger to public safety. They are also charged with causing polluted matter to enter controlled waters, the agency said.
The spill caused considerable damage to wildlife in an area with some of the most important seabird colonies in Western Europe.
